notes.text:
[**2106-10-29**] 10:09 AM
 MR HEAD W/ CONTRAST                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 31596**]
 Reason: Pre-surgical MRI
  Contrast: MAGNEVIST Amt: 15CC
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 MRI OF THE BRAIN WITH GADOLINIUM

 HISTORY:  Brain mass.

 Comparison is made with [**2106-10-11**].

 Accounting for differences in head angulation and positioning, there is slight
 increase in the right parietal lobe mass but with decrease in the surrounding
 edema.  The right frontal lobe lesion currently measures 2.2 cm CC x 2.7 cm AP
 x 2.5 cm TV dimensions compared to prior measurements of 2.2 x 1.7 x 2.0 cm.
  There is less mass effect on the ventricles.
  There is also a subtle enhancing lesion in the left cerebellum adjacent to
 the tentorium.  Ventricles and sulci are unchanged in size and configuration.
 There is no acute ischemia.

 IMPRESSION:

 Right frontal lobe mass appears to be minimally increased in size, although
 there is decreased surrounding edema.  No significant change in tiny left
 cerebellar lesion.

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Crainiotomy for tumor resection


History of Present Illness:
This is a 65-year-old gentleman who initially
presented with left hand numbness as well as tingling
associated with difficulty placing his hand in space. His
work-up ultimately included MRI of the head that revealed a
right parietal mass, as well as a small contrast enhancing
region in the left cerebellum consistent with metastasis.
Work-up revealed a left upper lung mass as well. The patient
presents for a combined mediastinoscopy as well as a right
craniotomy for tumor resection. The mediastinoscopy will be
separately dictated by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].


Past Medical History:
HTN
Hypercholesterolemia
BPH (prostate bx 18 mo ago negative)
Seasonal allergies

Social History:

Alcohol: 2 beers per night
Illicits: denies, no IVDA.
No herbal remedies.


Family History:
Father - died of CHF aged 89
Mother - died of a stroke aged 73 (also had rheumatoid
arthritis)
4 Siblings:
Non-identical twin siblings: brother has ulcerative colitis and

sister has diverticulitis
One sister died of AML aged 55
A brother has OA

Physical Exam:
A&Ox3, PERRL, follows commands, tongue midline, smile symmetric,
no pronator drift. Strength is full [**5-31**]. Poor coordination of
his left hand (baseline)

Pertinent Results:
MRI [**10-31**]:There is a new right frontal/parietal craniotomy.
Subacute blood
products are present at the site of the resected right frontal
mass. There is hyperemia and mild linear enhancement along the
medial and superior margins of the surgical cavity. There is a
small right subdural collection, a small right epidural
collection, and a small right subgaleal collection. Vasogenic
edema in the right cerebral hemisphere has decreased in extent
compared to [**2106-10-11**]. A 4 mm enhancing mass in the
left cerebellar hemisphere is unchanged. A left parietal
development venous anomaly is again seen. No new enhancing
lesions are seen. The ventricles are normal in size.

MRI [**10-29**]: Head Accounting for differences in head angulation and
positioning, there is slight increase in the right parietal lobe
mass but with decrease in the surrounding edema. The right
frontal lobe lesion currently measures 2.2 cm CC x 2.7 cm AP x
2.5 cm TV dimensions compared to prior measurements of 2.2 x 1.7
x 2.0 cm. There is less mass effect on the ventricles.
There is also a subtle enhancing lesion in the left cerebellum
adjacent to
the tentorium. Ventricles and sulci are unchanged in size and
configuration. There is no acute ischemia.

Brief Hospital Course:
On [**10-29**] Mr. [**Known lastname **] [**Last Name (Titles) 1834**] a R Parietal Crani for tumor
resection. During that time he [**Last Name (Titles) 1834**] a biopsy of his LUL by
Thoracics. He tolerated both procedures well and was trasferred
to the floor where he was neurologically stable. He did have LUE
ataxia and alt. proprioception which was at his baseline during
that time.

He did have confusion during the night on a couple of occasions
and on [**11-1**] had a fall and hit head. There was a sm. amount of
new blood on CT however pt was neurologically stable. Subsequent
CTs revealed no evidence of hematoma expansion.  His neurologic
status continued to improve.  By POD2, he was consistently
coherent and without episodes of confusion.

Routine post-op serum electrolyte check revealed that he was
hyponatremic (Na 132) and was started on fluid restriction and
salt tabs. The restriction and salt tab was tapered
subsequently.  By the time of discharge, his Na was 133 without
fluid restriction or salt taps.

The patient has a history of Prostatic Hypertrophy and had
voiding difficulties post-op.  The urology service was called
and a foley was placed.  Per urology recommendation, the patient
will go home with the Foley and a leg bag.  He will follow up
with the urology service after discharge.

The patient took in adequate POs and he worked well with PT/OT
and was cleared for home with PT services.  His left hand
coordination had significantly improved by the time of
discharge.

Flomax

ASA

 right frontal mass resection.

 COMPARISON:  Preoperative studies of [**10-29**], and [**2106-10-11**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Sagittal T1-weighted and axial T1-weighted, T2-weighted, FLAIR,
 gradient echo, and diffusion-weighted images of the brain were obtained.
 Following intravenous gadolinium administration, multiplanar T1-weighted
 images of the brain were obtained.

 products are present at the site of the resected right frontal mass.  There is
 hyperemia and mild linear enhancement along the medial and superior margins of
 the surgical cavity.  There is a small right subdural collection, a small
 right epidural collection, and a small right subgaleal collection.  Vasogenic
 edema in the right cerebral hemisphere has decreased in extent compared to
 [**2106-10-11**].  A 4 mm enhancing mass in the left cerebellar hemisphere
 is unchanged.  A left parietal developmental venous anomaly is again seen. No
 new enhancing lesions are seen. The ventricles are normal in size.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Expected postoperative changes status post right frontal mass resection.
 2.  Unchanged 4 mm left cerebellar mass.
                                                                       DFDkq

 [**Hospital 3**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  65 year old man with Right parietal mass s/p resection.
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  assess for changes. TO BE DONE WITHIN 4 HRS POST-OP.
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 PROVISIONAL FINDINGS IMPRESSION (PFI): JXKc FRI [**2106-10-29**] 10:02 PM
  PFI:  Expected post-operative changes following a right parietal craniotomy
  with right parietal lobe mass resection, with a small amount of post-operative
  blood products and pneumocephalus.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  65-year-old male with right parietal mass status post resection.
 Assess for changes.

 COMPARISON:  [**2106-10-10**] and MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**2106-10-29**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images of the head were obtained without IV
 contrast.

 FINDINGS:  Patient is status post right parietal craniotomy, with resection of
 a right parietal mass.  There are expected post-operative changes, with a tiny
 amount of post-operative hemorrhage and pneumocephalus within the surgical bed
 and overlying the right frontal lobe anteriorly.  There continues to be
 residual vasogenic edema within the right parietal lobe.  There is no shift of
 normally midline structures or acute major vascular territorial infarction.
 The ventricles and sulci are normal in caliber and configuration.  The left
 maxillary sinus is atelectatic with mild mucosal thickening. Osseous
 structures reveal craniotomy defect of the right parietal bone, with soft
 tissue swelling and subcutaneous air overlying the right craniotomy site.

 IMPRESSION:  Expected post-operative changes following right parietal mass
 resection, with a small amount of post-operative hemorrhage and
 pneumocephalus.

  1.  No interval change from the most recent prior, in the extra-axial
  hemorrhage, underlying the craniotomy site, with mild local mass effect.
  2.  Postoperative changes right parietal lobe, with small amount of hemorrhage
  and pneumocephalus within the operative bed, unchanged.
  3.  No new foci of hemorrhage identified.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  65-year-old male with new blood, evaluate for any increase in blood.

 COMPARISON:  [**2106-11-1**] at 4:58 a.m.

 TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images of the head were obtained without IV
 contrast.

 FINDINGS:  Again noted are post-surgical changes following a right parietal
 mass resection, with a small amount of hemorrhage and pneumocephalus within
 the surgical bed and pneumocephalus overlying the right frontal lobe. There is
 associated vasogenic edema that is slightly increased from [**2106-10-29**],
 but unchanged from 4:58 a.m. An extra- axial hemorrhage underlying the
 craniotomy site measures approximately 1.5 cm in maximal dimensions, with
 adjacent local mass effect. The size of this extra- axial hemorrhage is
 unchanged from the prior study.

 There are no new foci of intracranial hemorrhage, shift of normally midline
 structures, or acute major vascular territorial infarction. Ventricles and
 sulci are unchanged in caliber and configuration. Visualized paranasal sinuses
 and mastoid air cells are normally aerated. Osseous structures demonstrate a
 right parietal craniotomy. Again noted is soft tissue swelling and hemorrhage
 within the soft tissues overlying the craniotomy site, unchanged.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  No interval change in the extra-axial hemorrhage underlying the craniotomy
 site, with associated local mass effect on the adjacent brain parenchyma.

 2.  No interval change from the most recent study in the post-surgical changes
 following right parietal lobe mass resection, with a small amount of
 hemorrhage and pneumocephalus within the surgical bed.

                                                             (Over)

 [**2106-11-1**] 2:38 AM
 CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST                                            Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 233**]
 Reason: please assess for interval change
 Admitting Diagnosis: RIGHT PARIETAL BRAIN TUMOR/SDA
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 4**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  65 year old man s/p R parietal mass rxn, recent fall
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  please assess for interval change
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT  (REVISED)
 HISTORY:  Status post right parietal mass resection, recent fall.

 COMPARISON:  [**2106-10-29**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Non-contrast head CT.

 CT OF THE HEAD WITHOUT CONTRAST:  Post-surgical changes from right parietal
 mass resection are again noted.  The amount of surrounding edema in the
 surgical bed appears slightly larger since prior exam.  No hyperdense foci
 within the surgical bed suggestive of hemorrhage.  There is no shift of
 normally midline structures, hydrocephalus, or infarct.  Small amount of
 pneumocephalus is again seen.  The osseous structures demonstrate right
 parietal craniectomy with post-surgical changes within the soft tissues.

 IMPRESSION:  Interval increase in the size of vasogenic edema around the
 surgical bed.  A few small hyperdense foci within the surgical bed suggestive
 of hemorrhage.

 NOTE ADDED AT ATTENDING REVIEW: There is a new extra axial hemorrhage
 underlying the craniotomy. This produces mild local mass effect, but there is
 no evidence of new intraparenchymal bleeding. There is also increased
 hemorrhage within the scalp flap.

 Reason: Please evaluate for any new or worsening hematoma
 Admitting Diagnosis: RIGHT PARIETAL BRAIN TUMOR/SDA
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 4**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  65 year old man s/p crani with new blood at the surgical site yesterday after
  falling
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please evaluate for any new or worsening hematoma
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 PROVISIONAL FINDINGS IMPRESSION (PFI): DFDkq TUE [**2106-11-2**] 6:33 PM
  No interval change.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Status post right parietal mass resection with new blood at the
 surgical site yesterday after falling.

 COMPARISON:  [**2106-11-1**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Non-contrast head CT.

 FINDINGS:  Blood products in the right frontal/parietal resection cavity
 appear stable.  Surrounding vasogenic edema is stable.  The epidural
 hemorrhagic collection underlying the right frontal/parietal craniotomy is
 stable in extent and density.  The right subgaleal collection is also stable.
 The ventricles are stable in size, with persistent effacement of the occipital
 [**Doctor Last Name 39**] of the right lateral ventricle.  No new abnormalities are seen.

 IMPRESSION:  No interval change.
                                                                       DFDkq
